Home / Rehabilitation / Suprascapular Nerve

Rehabilitation After Suprascapular Nerve Decompression

Your complete guide to recovery after arthroscopic nerve release surgery. Evidence-based program designed to restore strength and function safely.

Important Note

This program is based on current evidence and clinical protocols, but every patient is unique. Always follow your surgeon's specific instructions and consult your physiotherapist before progressing between phases.

Understanding Your Surgery

You have undergone arthroscopic suprascapular nerve decompression ‚Äì a minimally invasive keyhole procedure to release pressure on the suprascapular nerve. This nerve controls the supraspinatus and infraspinatus muscles, which are essential for shoulder strength and stability.

Pain Relief

Often within days to weeks

Strength Recovery

Gradual over 3‚Äì6 months

Full Recovery

Most patients at 6‚Äì12 months

‚ö†Ô∏è What to Expect

  • ‚Ä¢ Nerve healing is slow ‚Äì Recovery depends on nerve regeneration (approximately 1mm per day). Full recovery can continue for up to 12 months. Early motion prevents frozen shoulder.
  • ‚Ä¢ Atrophy may be partially irreversible ‚Äì Some muscle wasting from long-standing compression may not fully recover, but function typically improves significantly
  • ‚Ä¢ Patience is key ‚Äì Rushing rehabilitation can lead to setbacks. Follow the phases carefully

Immediate Post-Surgery (Days 0-3)

‚úì

Cold/Heat Therapy

First 3-5 days (Cold): Apply ice or cold pack for 15-20 minutes, 3-4 times daily to reduce swelling and pain. Use a reusable "hot/cold gel pack" from freezer or ice (in a plastic bag) wrapped in cloth.

After day 5 (Heat optional): If muscles feel stiff, you may use the same gel pack heated (microwave or warm water) to relax muscles before exercises. Always protect skin with cloth.

‚úì

Pain Management

Take prescribed pain medication as directed. Some discomfort is normal but severe pain should be reported.

‚ö†Ô∏è

Contact Your Doctor Immediately If:

  • Fever above 38¬∞C
  • General feeling of illness or chills after the operation
  • Wound problems, such as:
    • The wound does not dry out
    • The wound does not heal
    • Fluid or discharge from the wound

Rehabilitation Phases

Phase 1
Weeks 0‚Äì4

Protection & early motion

Phase 2
Weeks 4‚Äì8

Active ROM & light strengthening

Phase 3
Weeks 8‚Äì12

Progressive strengthening

Phase 4
Week 12+

Return to activity

1

Phase 1: Protection & Early Motion

Weeks 0‚Äì4 Post-Surgery

Goals

  • ‚Ä¢ Protect surgical site and allow initial healing
  • ‚Ä¢ Reduce pain and inflammation
  • ‚Ä¢ Prevent shoulder stiffness
  • ‚Ä¢ Maintain elbow/wrist/hand motion
  • ‚Ä¢ Begin gentle passive range of motion (ROM)

Exercises - Phase 1

All exercises should be pain-free or minimal discomfort only.

1. Pendulum Exercises (Days 1-7)

Lean forward, support yourself with your good arm on a table. Let the operated arm hang freely and gently swing it:

  • ‚Ä¢ Forward and backward (10 swings)
  • ‚Ä¢ Side to side (10 swings)
  • ‚Ä¢ Small circles clockwise and counterclockwise (10 each direction)

Frequency: 3-4 times daily

2. Passive Range of Motion - Flexion (Week 1-4)

Lie on your back. Use your good arm or a stick/wand to gently lift your operated arm overhead.

  • ‚Ä¢ Start with 90¬∞ (arm straight up)
  • ‚Ä¢ Progress to 120-150¬∞ by week 4
  • ‚Ä¢ Hold for 5-10 seconds

Frequency: 10 repetitions, 2-3 times daily

3. Passive External Rotation (Week 2-4)

Lie on your back with elbow at 90¬∞. Use your good hand or a stick to gently rotate your arm outward.

  • ‚Ä¢ Start gently, to tolerance
  • ‚Ä¢ Progress to 30-45¬∞ external rotation
  • ‚Ä¢ Do NOT force into pain

Frequency: 10 repetitions, 2-3 times daily

4. Scapular Sets (Week 1-4)

Sit with good posture. Gently squeeze shoulder blades together and down toward back pockets. Prevents hunching forward.

Frequency: 10 repetitions holding 5 seconds, 2-3 times daily

5. Elbow/Wrist/Hand Motion

Keep your elbow, wrist, and hand mobile to prevent stiffness.

  • ‚Ä¢ Elbow flexion/extension (10 reps)
  • ‚Ä¢ Wrist circles (10 each direction)
  • ‚Ä¢ Finger flexion/extension (10 reps)

Frequency: Multiple times daily

üö´ Precautions - Phase 1

  • ‚Ä¢ No cross-body stretch ‚Äì Avoid pulling arm across chest (puts tension on healing nerve)
  • ‚Ä¢ No active lifting of the arm (wait until Phase 2)
  • ‚Ä¢ No resistance exercises
  • ‚Ä¢ No reaching behind back
  • ‚Ä¢ No heavy lifting or pushing
  • ‚Ä¢ Avoid sleeping on the operated shoulder

Progress to Phase 2 When:

  • ‚úì Minimal pain at rest
  • ‚úì Passive ROM at least 120¬∞ flexion, 30¬∞ external rotation
  • ‚úì Cleared by your physiotherapist or surgeon (typically week 4)
2

Phase 2: Active ROM & Light Strengthening

Weeks 4‚Äì8 Post-Surgery

Goals

  • ‚Ä¢ Achieve full passive ROM
  • ‚Ä¢ Begin active ROM without pain
  • ‚Ä¢ Start gentle isometric strengthening
  • ‚Ä¢ Improve scapular control
  • ‚Ä¢ Gradually restore daily function

Exercises - Phase 2

Continue passive ROM from Phase 1, add active exercises as tolerated.

1. Active-Assisted Flexion & Wall Slide (Week 4-6)

Method 1: Use your good arm or cane/stick to assist lifting the operated arm overhead.
Method 2 (Wall Slide): Stand facing wall, place towel under hand, slide hand up wall as high as comfortable without shrugging shoulder.

  • ‚Ä¢ Gradually reduce assistance as strength improves
  • ‚Ä¢ Progress to full active flexion by week 8

Frequency: 10-15 repetitions, 2-3 times daily

2. Active External Rotation (Week 5-8)

Stand with elbow at side, bent to 90¬∞. Slowly rotate arm outward (away from body). This exercise is critical for infraspinatus recovery.

  • ‚Ä¢ Start without resistance
  • ‚Ä¢ Progress slowly ‚Äì this muscle has been weak

Frequency: 10-15 repetitions, 2-3 times daily

3. Isometric Exercises - "The Statue" (Week 6-8)

Gentle muscle activation without moving the joint. Push against a wall with 25% effort ‚Äì like a statue holding position.

  • ‚Ä¢ External rotation: Stand with back of hand against wall, elbow at 90¬∞. Gently press outward (hold 5 sec)
  • ‚Ä¢ Abduction: Stand with outside of elbow against wall. Press outward (hold 5 sec)
  • ‚Ä¢ Flexion: Push forward against wall with palm (hold 5 sec)

Frequency: 10 repetitions each, once daily

4. Supine Active Punch - Serratus Activation (Week 6-8)

Lie on your back with arm pointing to ceiling, elbow straight. "Punch" fist higher by lifting shoulder blade off surface. Lower slowly.

Frequency: 2 sets of 10 repetitions, daily

4. Scapular Retraction (Week 4-8)

Sitting or standing, squeeze shoulder blades together. Hold for 5 seconds.

Frequency: 10-15 repetitions, 2 times daily

‚ö†Ô∏è Precautions - Phase 2

  • ‚Ä¢ Continued caution with cross-body stretching
  • ‚Ä¢ No heavy lifting (>2kg / 5 lbs)
  • ‚Ä¢ No forceful overhead activities
  • ‚Ä¢ Stop if sharp pain occurs
  • ‚Ä¢ Progress gradually ‚Äì nerve healing takes time

Progress to Phase 3 When:

  • ‚úì Full passive ROM achieved
  • ‚úì Active ROM at least 140¬∞ flexion, 40¬∞ external rotation
  • ‚úì Minimal pain with daily activities
  • ‚úì Typically around week 8
3

Phase 3: Progressive Strengthening

Weeks 8‚Äì12 Post-Surgery

Goals

  • ‚Ä¢ Restore full active ROM
  • ‚Ä¢ Progressive strengthening of rotator cuff
  • ‚Ä¢ Improve shoulder stability and endurance
  • ‚Ä¢ Normalize scapular mechanics
  • ‚Ä¢ Return to light functional activities

Exercises - Phase 3

1. Resistance Band - External Rotation

Stand with elbow at side, bent 90¬∞. Hold resistance band and rotate arm outward against resistance.

  • ‚Ä¢ Start with light resistance (yellow/red Theraband)
  • ‚Ä¢ Critical for infraspinatus recovery
  • ‚Ä¢ Progress resistance as strength improves

Frequency: 2-3 sets of 15 repetitions, daily

2. "Full Can" Exercise - Supraspinatus (Week 8-12)

Stand holding light weight (1-2 lbs). Lift arm out to side and slightly forward (30¬∞ angle), thumb pointing UP (like holding a full can). Lift only to shoulder height.

  • ‚Ä¢ Important: Do NOT turn thumb down ("Empty Can") ‚Äì this stresses the healing area
  • ‚Ä¢ Slow, controlled motion

Frequency: 3 sets of 10-12 repetitions, 3-4 times weekly

3. Scapular Strengthening - Rows

Hold resistance band with both hands. Pull elbows back, squeezing shoulder blades together.

Frequency: 2 sets of 15 repetitions, daily

4. Wall Push-Ups (Week 10-12)

Face a wall, hands at shoulder height. Perform push-up motion against wall.

  • ‚Ä¢ Start with gentle motion
  • ‚Ä¢ Progress to regular push-ups on knees in Phase 4

Frequency: 2 sets of 10-15 repetitions, daily

Precautions - Phase 3

  • ‚Ä¢ Avoid heavy overhead lifting
  • ‚Ä¢ No sudden jerking movements
  • ‚Ä¢ Listen to your body ‚Äì some muscle soreness is normal, sharp pain is not

Progress to Phase 4 When:

  • ‚úì Full active ROM without pain
  • ‚úì Strength improving (can perform daily tasks without difficulty)
  • ‚úì No pain with resistance exercises
  • ‚úì Typically around week 12
4

Phase 4: Return to Activity

Week 12+ Post-Surgery

Goals

  • ‚Ä¢ Return to full functional activities
  • ‚Ä¢ Sport-specific training (if applicable)
  • ‚Ä¢ Maximize strength and endurance
  • ‚Ä¢ Maintain long-term shoulder health

Exercises - Phase 4

Progress to heavier resistance and functional movements based on your goals.

1. Progressive Resistance Training

Increase resistance on all rotator cuff exercises:

  • ‚Ä¢ External rotation with heavier bands or light dumbbells (1-3 kg)
  • ‚Ä¢ Abduction with resistance
  • ‚Ä¢ Internal rotation exercises

Frequency: 3 sets of 12-15 repetitions, 3-4 times weekly

2. Scapular Stabilization - Advanced

Plank variations, push-ups, and dynamic stability exercises.

  • ‚Ä¢ Wall planks progressing to floor planks
  • ‚Ä¢ Push-ups on knees ‚Üí full push-ups
  • ‚Ä¢ Shoulder taps in plank position

Frequency: 2-3 sets, 3 times weekly

3. Plyometric Training (Athletes, Week 16+)

Dynamic, explosive exercises for sport preparation:

  • ‚Ä¢ Wall dribbling: Throw small weighted ball against wall, catch and repeat
  • ‚Ä¢ Rebounder throws: Medicine ball throws on trampoline rebounder
  • ‚Ä¢ Start light, progress gradually

Frequency: 2-3 times weekly

4. Work Hardening (if applicable)

Simulate your specific work tasks with progressively increasing loads:

  • ‚Ä¢ Lifting boxes, reaching high shelves, repetitive overhead work
  • ‚Ä¢ Start with light loads, increase gradually over weeks
  • ‚Ä¢ Coordinate with occupational therapist if heavy manual labor

Return to Sport Timeline

Based on high-quality evidence, most athletes can return to sport within 3-8 months after surgery, with 92-98% successfully returning to their pre-injury level.

  • ‚Ä¢ Non-contact sports: 3-4 months (swimming, cycling, running)
  • ‚Ä¢ Overhead sports: 4-6 months (tennis, volleyball, baseball)
  • ‚Ä¢ Contact sports: 6-8 months (hockey, rugby)

Long-Term Maintenance

Even after completing your formal rehabilitation, it's important to maintain shoulder health:

Continue Strengthening

Perform scapular retraction and theraband external rotation exercises at least 2 times weekly to maintain shoulder health and prevent weakness.

Proper Warm-Up

Always warm up before sports or heavy activities. 5-10 minutes of gentle ROM and activation exercises.

Listen to Your Body

Some fatigue in infraspinatus is normal initially. Adjust activity if pain persists.

References & Evidence Base

This rehabilitation program is based on the following clinical protocols and scientific evidence:

Rothman Orthopaedics - Suprascapular Nerve Decompression PT Protocol

Brandon J. Erickson, MD

Denver Shoulder Surgeon - Rehabilitation Protocol for Suprascapular Nerve Decompression
Steven Chudik MD - Suprascapular Nerve Release Protocol (Updated 2024)
AAOS - Arthroscopic Suprascapular Nerve Decompression (2025)
PubMed: Novel techniques in suprascapular nerve neurolysis (PMID 36515356)
PubMed: Rehabilitation in athletes after nerve decompression (PMID 17187259)

This program synthesizes recommendations from multiple evidence-based sources. Individual progression may vary based on pre-operative weakness severity, degree of muscle atrophy, and patient-specific factors. Always consult with your healthcare team for personalized guidance.
